Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: MUSE: An Integrated Approach to Managing Uncertain Scientific Experimental Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Science is becoming increasingly data intensive. As the experimental data starts to accumulate within or across institutions and over time, it is indeed a valuable wealth of information. However, little has been done to query the data repository in an integrated manner, mainly because the results among different replicates of an experiment often show a large degree of inconsistency and variance. This database poses unique challenges in data types, query types, and accuracy of distributions, etc. The broad goal of the project is to solve some major query processing challenges in such a database.

Specific techniques used to achieve this goal include: (1) Coupling top-k query answering with computation of the score distribution of top-k tuples, and the novel usage of this framework in a number of contexts; (2) Measuring the accuracy of probability distributions which affects user?s perception of query results, and devising new predicates for decision making; (3) Proposing novel semantics and efficient query processing for join queries on uncertain data; and (4) Designing a suite of algorithms for approximate substring matching and windowed subsequence matching for online monitoring queries.

The ability to effectively and accurately share, query, and monitor diverse scientific experimental data on a large scale will greatly benefit the science community. The extra data analysis capability provided to scientists can even change the way they conduct their research. The education plan includes teaching both computer science students on managing scientific data and science major students on relevant database techniques, attracting middle school and college students into computer science, and inspiring students of underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI and the students who work on this project have accomplished all the major goals of this project. Specifically, they have done several lines of work on answering top-k queries for uncertain, probabilistic, or incomplete data in various contexts including relational tables, data streams, and graphs as found in scientific data applications. They have tackled the problems related to decision-making under uncertainty, including approaches that use reinforcement learning to make sequential decisions that have impact in the long term.  The PI and students have studied, in various contexts, data and information correlation and use statistical models that leverage this correlation for data analysis and prediction.  Moreover, they have performed a series of work on pattern matching in sequence data, ranging from substring and subsequence matching to approximate and interleaving complex event matching in data streams, and to novel event semantics and matching algorithms in graph streams. 

The broader impact of the project includes working with scientists in a number of domains including biomedical science, transportation science, mechanical and material sciences, and social sciences.  Research results from the project have been published in major data management and data mining conferences.  Furthermore, the research results out of this project have also been incorporated in teaching and course materials, as well as the publications and dissertations of several students who have participated in the project.


Last Modified: 06/17/2019
Modified by: Tingjian Ge
